Lewat Sekolah Abal-Abal, Bobby Singh Tipu Pemerintah Australia Rp 20 Miliar
06 Nov 2019, 03:17 by ABC
Selama empat tahun, Bobby Singh mendapatkan penghasilan lebih dari Rp 20 mliar dari subsidi Pemerintah Australia bagi mahasiswa yang terdaftar di "sekolah kejuruan" abal-abal di Melbourne.
Sekolah Abal-Abal di Australia:

Bobby Singh adalah pemilik "sekolah kejuruan abal-abal" bernama St Stephen Institute of Technology
Singh menjalankan "sekolah" itu untuk mendapatkan subsidi pemerintah bernilai jutaan dolar
Singh sudah dijatuhi vonis kurungan penjara selama enam tahun

Sekolah itu sama sekali tidak memiliki mahasiswa. Penipuan ini pun terbongkar dari sebuah percakapan telepon yang berlangsung selama 4 menit 38 detik.
Pada 1 Juli 2015, Singh mendapat panggilan telepon dari seorang petugas Badan Otoritas Pemantau Mutu Pendidikan Australia (ASQA).
"Selamat pagi Pak Singh. Saya menelpon karena saya diminta untuk memantau fasilitas sekolah Anda," kata petugas bernama Kate Owen kepada Singh.
"Dari waktu ke waktu, kami memang datang ke lokasi, mengecek berbagai dokumen, memeriksa apakah aturan ditaati atau tidak."
Bobby Singh adalah pemilik "sekolah kejuruan" bernama St Stephen Institute of Technology di Melbourne.
Saat itu, Singh mengatakan bahwa dia siap menerima kunjungan tim pemantau.
Ketika pembicaraan selesai, Singh langsung menelpon mitranya Mukesh Sharma, yang menjalankan sekolah lain bernama Symbiosis Institute of Technical Education.
Dia mengatakan kepada Sharma untuk bersiap-siap, karena akan ada pemeriksaan.
Yang tidak diketahui Singh dan Sharma ketika itu adalah bahwa pembicaraan mereka direkam oleh penyidik federal.
Pembicaraan itu kemudian menjadi bukti penipuan yang dilakukan Singh dan rekannya terhadap Pemerintah Australia. Mereka menipu untuk mendapatkan subsidi lebih dari $AUD 2 juta (sekitar Rp 20 miliar).
Bentuk penipuan ini dikenal dengan istilah "sekolah abal-abal".


Polisi menyita mobil Ferrari dari rumah Bobby Singh di kawasan elit Melbourne, Balwyn. AFP Media

Kesempatan baru
Ketika akhirnya kasusnya dibawa ke pengadilan, Hakim Michael O'Connell mengakui bahwa Bobby Singh "sebenarnya sudah banyak melakukan hal yang baik sebelumnya."
Singh tiba di Australia tahun 1999 ketika berusia 18 tahun, dan kemudian terlibat dalam beberapa kegiatan bisnis wirausaha.
Dia menjalankan bisnis keamanan di tahun 2003. Di tahun 2005 dia menjadi subkontraktor bagi Australia Post, dengan menjadi pengirim barang ke berbagai daerah di Melbourne.
Menurut berkas pengadilan, usahanya itu berkembang pesat dengan nilai lebih dari $AUD 1,75 juta.
Tahun 2011, Singh menemukan "bisnis baru", yaitu menjadi pemilik sebuah "sekolah kejuruan" bernama St Stephen Institute of Technology.
Singh melihat hal ini sebagai sebuah kesempatan baru.
Perubahan gaya hidup
Ketika petugas ASQA menelepon Singh di tahun 2015, pihak berwenang menduga bahwa Singh akan panik.
Detektif Danielle Woodward sudah memantau Singh dan rekannya selama enam bulan setelah adanya laporan mengenai surat kelakuan baik mereka.
Petugas mencurigai adanya beberapa hal yang aneh yang sedang terjadi.
Singh tinggal di rumah mewah dengan mobil Ferrari, dan sumber kemewahannya tidak jelas asalnya.
Sekolahnya berada di lokasi yang aneh dan aktivitasnya tidak sebanyak sekolah normal dengan ratusan orang mahasiswa.


Mukesh Sharma pemilik dan pengelola Symbiosis Institute of Technical Education di Footscray.

Singh kemudian mulai mempersiapkan kunjungan tim ASQA.
ABC mendapatkan hasil pembicaraan telepon dan rekaman video yang menunjukkan usaha penipuan Singh dan rekan-rekannya.
Di hari ketika tim berkunjung, Singh melakukan beberapa pembicaraan telepon dengan anggota sindikatnya Mukesh Sharma dan Rakesh Kumar â€” untuk mempersiapkan dokumen.
Dalam salah satu pembicaraan, salah seorang anggota sindikat mengatakan kepada Singh, "kita tahu bahwa yang kita lakukan ini secara hukum dan secara etika salah."
Ternyata dari berbagai rekaman rahasia yang mereka lakukan di sekolah tersebut, kegiatan pengajaran tidaklah berlangsung di sana.

A cleaner is the only person who appears at the college in this surveillance footage. ( ABC News )
"Pada dasarnya kami menemukan tidak adanya kegiatan pengajaran dan tidak adanya mahasiswa yang terlibat dalam kegiatan pendidikan," kata Danielle Woodward.
Salah satu kegiatan yang paling tampak di sekolah tersebut adalah ketika hari pengecekan ditentukan.
"Kami melihat adanya komputer dan berbagai dokumen dibawa ke sana," kata Woodward lagi.
"Namun komputer itu sama sekali tidak disambungkan ke internet. Jadi sebenarnya dibawa ke sana hanya sekedar untuk diperlihatkan kepada tim pemantau."

Surveillance footage shows people carrying computer...

Surveillance footage shows people carrying computer equipment into the college. ( ABC News )
Bentuk penipuan seperti ini dikenal oleh mereka yang bekerja di sektor sekolah kejuruan di Australia sebagai "sekolah hantu."
"Sekolah itu seolah-olah melakukan kegiatan," kata Larissa Kernebone, seorang mantan pengawasa ASQA yang sekarang menjadi konsultan sekolah kejuruan.
"Jadi mereka terlihat seperti sekolah kejuruan, namun para siswa sama sekali tidak pernah sekolah, mereka bekerja di tempat lain atau melakukan sesuatu yang lain."
Bagaimana penipuan terjadi
Menurut polisi ada dua bentuk penipuan yang dilakukan Singh dan teman-temannya.
Di Australia ada sistem bantuan keuangan untuk siswa yang dikenal dengan istilah VET FEE-HELP dimana mahasiswa internasional bisa bersekolah di sekolah kejuruan swasta dengan bantuan pinjaman dari pemerintah.
Sekolah kejuruan kemudian mendapat dana dari pemerintah tergantung dari jumlah murid yang mendaftar.
"Mereka pada dasarnya mendapat uang dengan mudah," kata Detektif Woodward.
"Mereka mengambil uang tersebut dan pada dasarnya mengatakan kepada siswa bahwa anda tidak perlu datang, dan mereka akan memberikan sertifikat."
Dampak dari penipuan ini sangat buruk bagi beberapa mahasiswa internasional.
"Mereka datang ke Australia, membayar mahal untuk mendapatkan sertifikat dan pada dasarnya sertifikat itu palsu," kata Woodward lagi.
Terungkapnya kasus Singh pada waktu itu menimbulkan pemberitaan besar, dan membuat pemerintah Australia kemudian menghentikan pendanaan bagi mahasiswa lewat VET FEE-HELP.
Bentuk penipuan kedua adalah yang melibatkan mahasiswa yang tinggal di Australia.
Pemerintah negara bagian Victoria juga memberikan subsidi bagi mahasiswa yang masuk ke sekolah kejuruan.
"Siswa domestik ini banyak yang tidak tahu bahwa mereka terdaftar di sekolah tersebut," kata Woodward.
Salah seorangnya adalah Haripal Chahal yang baru saja menjadi warga negara Australia ketika rumahnya didatangi dua petugas polisi federal bulan Agustus 2015.


Haripal Chahal terkejut ketika mengetahui bahwa dia terdaftar sebagai mahasiswa di St Stephen Institute of Technology. ABC News: Paul Farrell

"Saya betul-betul ketakutan, karena saya takut mereka akan mendeportasi saya," kata Chahal kepada ABC.
Kedua petugas tersebut kemudian bertanya mengenai sekolah yang pernah diikuti dan sertifikat yang dimilikinya.
"Saya menunjukkan semua dokumen yang saya punyai dan mereka bertanya apakah saya pernah mengikuti kursus lainnya," kata Chahal lagi.
Chahal tidak pernah mendengar nama sekolah kejuruan St Stephen Institute of Technology yang disebut polisi.
Chahal terkejut ketika ditunjukkan bahwa dia pernah sekolah di situ, karena ada dokumen yang berisi data diri dan tandatangannya.
Dia tidak mengetahui bahwa identitasnya sudah dicuri dan dia menduga lewat petisi yang ditandatangani dalam sebuah acara yang melibatkan komunitas asal India.
"Saya sangat kecewa karena mereka menciptakan citra buruk bagi komunitas India," kata Chahal.
Dia termasuk satu dari 40 mahasiswa yang kemudian memberi kesaksian di pengadilan.
"Saya senang memberikan seluruh informasi yang saya punyai. Tidak ada yang perlu saya tutupi," katanya.
Ijazahnya tak berguna


Detektif Danielle Woodward bersama timnya menyelidiki kasus penipuan sekolah abal-abal di Melbourne. ABC News

Atas tindak penipuan ini, Bobby Singh sudah dijatuhi hukuman enam tahun penjara.
Rakesh Kumar dan Mukesh Sharma, yang juga merupakan pemain kunci dalam sindikat penipuan, dikenai hukuman lima tahun penjara.
Istri Singh, Rekha Arora yang juga dinyatakan bersalah dibebaskan dengan hukuman percobaan harus berkelakuan baik selama tiga tahun.
Dan sertifikat yang didapat para mahasiswa internasional dari sekolah tersebut sekarang tidak berguna sama sekali.
"Pada dasarnya mereka tertipu," kata Detektif Woodward.
"Mereka mendapat sertifikat, namun sertifikat itu tidak ada nilainya sama sekali dan mereka juga kehilangan uang."
"Mereka sebagian pulang ke negara masing-masing, dan itu membuat reputasi Australia juga tercemar."
Woodward mengatakan sekarang Kepolisian Federal Australia (AFP) terus melakukan pemantauan serius terhadap sektor sekolah kejuruan di negara ini.

Through Abal-Abal School, Bobby Singh Tipu Australian Government Rp. 20 Billion
Nov 6, 2019, 03:17 by ABC
For four years, Bobby Singh earns more than Rp 20 billion from Australian Government subsidies for students enrolled in a fake "vocational school" in Melbourne.
Abal-Abal Schools in Australia:

Bobby Singh is the owner of a "fake vocational school" named the St. Stephen Institute of Technology
Singh runs the "school" to get millions of dollars in government subsidies
Singh has been sentenced to prison for six years

The school has no students at all. This fraud was revealed from a telephone conversation that lasted for 4 minutes 38 seconds.
On 1 July 2015, Singh got a telephone call from an official of the Australian Education Quality Monitoring Agency (ASQA).
"Good morning Mr. Singh. I called because I was asked to monitor your school facilities," the officer named Kate Owen told Singh.
"From time to time, we do come to the location, check various documents, check whether the rules are obeyed or not."
Bobby Singh is the owner of a "vocational school" named the St. Stephen Institute of Technology in Melbourne.
At that time, Singh said that he was ready to accept the visit of the monitoring team.
When the conversation was over, Singh immediately called his partner Mukesh Sharma, who runs another school called the Symbiosis Institute of Technical Education.
He tells Sharma to get ready, because there will be an inspection.
What Singh and Sharma did not know at the time was that their conversation was recorded by federal investigators.
The conversation then became evidence of fraud committed by Singh and his colleagues against the Australian Government. They cheat to get a subsidy of more than $ AUD 2 million (around Rp. 20 billion).
This form of fraud is known as the "fake school".


Police seized a Ferrari from Bobby Singh's home in Melbourne's elite area of Balwyn. AFP Media

New opportunity
When his case was finally brought to justice, Judge Michael O'Connell admitted that Bobby Singh had "actually done a lot of good things before."
Singh arrived in Australia in 1999 when he was 18 years old, and later became involved in several entrepreneurial business activities.
He ran a security business in 2003. In 2005 he became a subcontractor for the Australia Post, sending goods to various parts of Melbourne.
According to court files, his business was growing rapidly with a value of more than $ AUD 1.75 million.
In 2011, Singh discovered a "new business", which was to become the owner of a "vocational school" called the St. Stephen's Institute of Technology.
Singh saw this as a new opportunity.
Lifestyle changes
When ASQA officers phoned Singh in 2015, authorities suspected that Singh would panic.
Detective Danielle Woodward has been monitoring Singh and his colleagues for six months after reports of their good behavior.
Officers suspect there are some strange things that are happening.
Singh lives in a luxury home in a Ferrari, and the source of his luxury is unclear.
The school is in a strange location and its activities are not as much as a normal school with hundreds of students.


Mukesh Sharma owner and manager of the Symbiosis Institute of Technical Education at Footscray.

Singh then began preparing for the ASQA team's visit.
ABC got the results of telephone conversations and video footage showing the fraudulent efforts of Singh and his colleagues.
On the day the team visited, Singh had several telephone conversations with members of his syndicate Mukesh Sharma and Rakesh Kumar - to prepare documents.
During one of the talks, one member of the syndicate told Singh, "we know that what we are doing is legally and ethically wrong."
It turns out that from various secret recordings they did at the school, teaching activities did not take place there.

A cleaner is the only person who appears at the college in this surveillance footage. (ABC News)
"Basically we found that there were no teaching activities and there were no students involved in educational activities," Danielle Woodward said.
One of the most visible activities at the school is when the checking day is determined.
"We saw computers and various documents brought there," said Woodward again.
"But the computer was not connected to the internet at all. So it was actually brought there only to be shown to the monitoring team."

Surveillance footage shows people carrying computer ...

Surveillance footage shows people carrying computer equipment into the college. (ABC News)
This form of fraud is known to those who work in the vocational school sector in Australia as "ghost schools."
"The school seems to be doing activities," said Larissa Kernebone, a former ASQA supervisor who is now a vocational school consultant.
"So they look like a vocational school, but the students never go to school, they work somewhere else or do something else."
How fraud occurs
According to the police there are two forms of fraud committed by Singh and his friends.
In Australia there is a financial assistance system for students known as VET FEE-HELP where international students can attend private vocational schools with loan assistance from the government.
Vocational schools then receive funding from the government depending on the number of students who register.
"They basically get money easily," Detective Woodward said.
"They took the money and basically told the students that you didn't need to come, and they would give certificates."
The impact of this fraud is very bad for some international students.
"They came to Australia, paid a fortune to get the certificate and basically the certificate was fake," Woodward said again.
Revelation of the Singh case at the time caused a great deal of news, and made the Australian government then stop funding for students through VET FEE-HELP.
The second form of fraud involves students living in Australia.
The Victoria state government also provides subsidies for students who enter vocational schools.
"Many domestic students don't know that they are enrolled in the school," Woodward said.
One of them was Haripal Chahal who had just become an Australian citizen when his home was visited by two federal police officers in August 2015.


Haripal Chahal was surprised to learn that she was registered as a student at the St. Stephen Institute of Technology. ABC News: Paul Farrell

"I was really scared, because I was afraid they would deport me," Chahal told ABC.
The two officers then asked about the school he had attended and the certificate he had.
"I showed all the documents I had and they asked me if I had ever taken another course," Chahal said again.
Chahal had never heard the name of the St. Stephen Institute of Technology vocational school called the police.
Chahal was surprised when it was shown that she had attended school there, because there were documents containing her personal data and her signature.
He did not know that his identity had been stolen and he suspected through a petition signed at an event involving an Indian community.
"I am very disappointed because they created a bad image for the Indian community," Chahal said.
He was one of 40 students who later testified in court.
"I am happy to give all the information I have. I have nothing to cover," he said.
The diploma is useless


Detective Danielle Woodward and his team investigate a case of fake school fraud in Melbourne. ABC News

For this fraud, Bobby Singh has been sentenced to six years in prison.
Rakesh Kumar and Mukesh Sharma, who are also key players in fraud syndicates, were sentenced to five years in prison.
Singh's wife, Rekha Arora who was also found guilty of being released on probation must behave for three years.
And certificates obtained by international students from these schools are now not useful at all.
"Basically they were fooled," Detective Woodward said.
"They got the certificate, but the certificate was of no value at all and they also lost money."
"They partly returned to their respective countries, and that made the reputation of Australia also tainted."
Woodward said that now the Australian Federal Police (AFP) continues to carry out serious monitoring of the vocational school sector in the country.
